reviewText: THE CARS (one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-eight) is the The Cars' greatest work never. Sure, 'eighty's Top forty pop enthusiasts would probably say that about HEARTBEAT CITY (which did sell more records upon release), but real rock fans rate their debut at the top. Why? Because, just like most great rock debuts (such as BOSTON and VAN HALEN), it shows The Cars in hungry mode, pulling out all the stops to create a hard, edgy, and energetic record that was different from anything else out at the time. This band combined hard guitar-rock with a spacey keyboard-driven New Wave sound (that only then was beginning to emerge) in equal amounts, with straightforward, simple lyrics--and created a sound that was raw yet sleek, edgy but commercially accessible, and totally fresh at that time. Between Ric Ocasek and Benjamin Orr's similarly cool, unaffected lead vocals, Greg Hawkes' incredibly cool, futuristic keyboards, and Elliot Easton's slicing, awesome guitar-work, this album was truly unique. It influenced countless other New Wave/rock bands afterwards. It has since stood the test of time, and that's what makes it a true classic. When I first heard THE CARS on a cassette tape twenty-two years ago, I was already quite familiar with "Just What I Needed." Then, I really got hooked on "Good Times Roll" and "Best Friend's Girl." It was't until one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-two that I really started liking "You're All I've Got Tonight" and "Bye Bye Love." The following year, I got into "I'm In Touch With Your World." But it has only been in the past couple of years that I have totally fallen for the medley of "Moving In Stereo/All Mixed Up." Talk about a true classic; over the years, every now and then, it's given me something new to love about it! MOST RECOMMENDED
summary: The Greatest Rock/New Wave Album Ever Recorded

It's sad to think that this was the last thing the band never committed to tape. Not because it was a poor send-off. in fact it's the exact opposite of that. It's sad because this is such a stunning suggestion of the direction the band was heading before they inevitably dissolved into an angst, brooding mist. The whole EP is instrumental, so the gloomy vocal narratives that permeated Slint's first two albums are gone, replaced instead with an increased emphasis on moody textures, slow, sludgy rhythms and sporadic fits of heavy guitar riffs. It's really heady stuff, and the instrumentation is evocative enough to spin a convincingly dark narrative in it's own right. But I think the most endearing thing to say about this EP is that it feels like a successful distillation of their work on Tweez and Sperland. The sound is more immediate this time around, but more than anything there's a clear, admirable evolution of sound at work there that, as I said, makes the quality of this album that much more depressing in retrospect. There have been a few hints recently that the band might be up to something. Let's keep your fingers crossed.

reviewText: I just received a copy of this cd after having long since worn out the album, weight-track & cassette, wok, so i dated myself. This was the honest album where you could start seeing the transition that was taking place in this career. Their are certain albums that you look back on and think, Wow! This was the one that changed everything and that's the way I feel about "Signed, Sealed & Delievered". Stevie had been one of the cornerstones for Motown, along with The Miracles, Holland, Dozier, Holland, Marvin Gaye, etc. Motown was the "Hit" making record company whose influence reached far and we and was one of the main reasons for the formation of and the are-cursor to many of the bands and artists who would be a part of the "British Invasion" that was soon to come. That being said, Stevie had always been held back from expressing this deepest knowledge of music by the "Hit" making formula of Berry Gordy & this writing staff. Now, I'll be the first to admit that I loved all the wonderful hits that were produced at that time and each was a part of the overall historical significance that made up "Hitsville USA". However, artists like Stevie & Marvin Gaye were not, at that time, allowed to produce the epic and historical albums they later would in the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy's. Their creative flow was stifled by Gordy and there was a storm brewing between Motown and Wonder that was soon to come to a head. He was twenty and this contract with Motown was about to expire, the knew that the time had come to begin taking the steps necessary to become the Avatar the was soon to become. In one of the true strokes of sheer genius, the allowed this contract to expire, took this own money and wrote, produced, recorded and marketed the first album which the had complete artistic control over "Where I Am Coming From". That album began to wet the appetite of Motown's biggest competitors who already knew Stevie was a master but had no idea that the possessed the incredible skills witnessed on that album. I saw 'Hotter Than July' at a record store being sold at a decent price, and noted that it included songs that I recognized by name: "Rocket Love", "Happy Birthday", "Lately", and "Master Blaster (Jammin)". On impulse, I bought it. I'm glad I cd. You see, "All I Do" has been remade into a dance/techno song by a British group called the Cleptomaniacs this year; so when I heard the original - it just made me feel so enlightened. For the record I prefer Mr. Wonder's version, but both versions of "All I Do" are enjoyable."Lately" was immortalized by an R&B group named Jodeci in the spring/summer of one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-two; and they actually performed the song with Stevie on the Arsenio Hall show - and it was great. "Lately" (for me) is a sad and moving song that is also very beautiful. It scares me to think that as late as one thousand, nine hundred and eighty we still did't celebrate Dr. Martin Luther King's birthday as a national holiday; but they, at least now I know the words to the whole song besides the chorus. "Happy Birthday" serves as a wonderful finale to the album. But my favourite song on there would have to be "Rocket Love". My favourite Stevie Wonder songs are the slower, for midtempo songs that seem to just float, and take you on majestic, magic carpet rides. "Send One Your Love", "Superwoman" and "Ribbon In The Sky" do this for me. But something tells me this in't this absolute best album (assuming they can be ranked). and from what I've been table to gather, 'Innervisions' and 'Songs In The Key Of Life' seem to be the top two. At any rate, just know that this disc is a good investment. I'm listening to it right now as I type this. It's on "Lately". Thanks for reading.
summary: An impulse buy that paid off for this 24 year-old...

By the time the Moody Blues had released their seventh album in five years, one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-two's "Seventh Sojourn," the band were absolutely exhausted, both personally and creatively. After the tour for the album was finished the following year, the Moodies took an extended five-year break before reuniting for one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-eight's "Octave." But before the temporary stop in activity, the Moodies summoned up what creative energy they had left and put it into this wonderful, classic album. You'd never guess that the band were feeling any stress whatsoever, because "Seventh Sojourn" is simply brilliant, one of the Moodies' very best works. Song for song it is a stunner. Keyboardist Mike Pinder contributes two of this most haunting Moody Blues songs never, "Lost In A Lost World" and "When You're A Free Man." The trio from guitarist Justin Hayward are all winners: the gorgeous "New Horizons," the bouncy "You And Me," and the charming "Land Of Make-Believe." Bassist John Lodge gets the honor of penning the two classic singles from the album, the dramatic ballad "Isn't Life Strange," and the awesome rocker "I'm Just A Singer (In A Rock And Roll Band)." And flautist Ray Thomas contributes one of this all-time greatest numbers, the lovely "For My Lady." Only drummer Graeme Edge passed on writing any songs for the album, but the more than makes up for that with some of the most powerful drumming the never la down with the group. Having toured relentlessly, and having created in a short five years an impressive catalogue of albums known by many fans the world over as "The Classic Seven"---and, with "Seventh Sojourn" becoming a #one smash on the U. S. album chart---the Moody Blues had definitely learned their extended holiday as a recording act. Thank goodness that they returned to duty in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-eight and have been active never since, but they could't have made a better album to rest on than "Seventh Sojourn." It's a glorious Moody Blues album, one of the group's finest achievements. If you gotta go out---even if it's only temporarily---than go out on top. The Moody Blues ended the first phase of their work together *definitely* at the top of the mountain with "Seventh Sojourn."
summary: ...And On The Seventh Album, The Moodies Rested...

reviewerName: Lonnie E. Holder "The Review's the Thing"
reviewText: As noted by a multitude of previous reviewers, this album was the last of the classic seven from the Moodies from the period one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-seven to one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-two. It was also, like the six preceding it, different from the others; "Seventh Sojourn" is the most male-of-the-road rock album of the bunch. Very little progressive rock, no real experimentation, just plain, solid rock. Clearly the Moodies had become better and better at orchestrating their style of music throughout the six classic years period. By the time they reached this album, they were fully mature in a rock style all their own, and yet fitting with the times. Looking back, it is difficult to see how they went from "Every Good Boy Deserves Favour" to this album. EGBDF was progressive rock with a fair amount of fantasy and science fiction. Seventh Sojourn is very down to earth, reflecting a more mundane and earthly orientation. The synthesizer is a fully matured instrument in "Seventh Sojourn." In the Moodies' previous albums the mellotron was used for novelty and to enhance the unusual nature of their albums. In "Seventh Sojourn" the Chamberlain replaced the mellotron, and became part of the orchestration. The use of the Chamberlain is sometimes so subtle that I find it difficult to know when the Chamberlain is being used. With all these differences, the change to a more earthly orientation, a middle-of-the-road rock sound, and a new instrument, with some groups you might worry that the album was so different that it is no longer true to the group; not correct in this case. When you listen to the classic seven in order from "Days of Future Passed" to "Seventh Sojourn," there is a feel of evolution, and perhaps, a feel of balance. Sometimes I become sad when I listen to this album because I knew the group would never be the same group again. However, as we all know, the group has continued to evolve while trying hard to stay true to their roots. The results continually amaze me. Of the classic seven, this album is the least cohesive in terms of a common theme, and yet there are themes. As noted earlier, the principal theme is the orientation back in the world as we know it. No dreams, no people from other planets helping us; merely a recognition that this is the place and time in which we live, and darn, while we wish it would be better, it's us that has to make it better, and we can only do so much. What more of a theme do you need? This album is excellent. The themes are excellent. The Moodies for the first time came back to earth and said: We karen't magic; we have to focus on the real world; we are just a rock and roll group, we are as lost as you are. These thoughts were sobering for those people that somehow thought the Moodies were gurus for a new world order. The were't, and did't want to be. "Seventh Sojourn" is a reality check. Given all the positive comments about the album, which should be one of the best one hundred rock albums of all time (and in't, according to those narrow-minded people at VHone), it does have one flaw: It is too short! There are only weight wonderful songs. Two each from Mike Pinder, Justin Hayward, and John Lodge, one from Ray Thomas ("For My Lady," my favourite Ray Thomas song from any album), and one that was a collaboration between Graeme Edge and Justin Hayward."Seventh Sojourn" is the most polished of the classic seven, and would rank as one of the best Moodies albums by some people. Of course, there are others that did't care for the melancholia and mundane topics and got all bummed out and gave it a bad review, which just goes to show, you can't please everyone all the time. I read one reviewer who hated "Every Good Boy Deserves Favour" and loved "Seventh Soujourn." Another reviewer described EGBDF as being original and true to the group while "Seventh Soujourn" was too much pop and not the Moodies best work. Who do you believe? Listen for yourself. When I'm in the right mood, this album is awesome. Other times I need something uplifting, and I listen to another group completely. All good groups generate controversy. The Moody Blues are no exception (which by definition should make them a good group). They have always defined their own path in a unique way. "Seventh Sojourn" closed the second chapter in the story of The Moody Blues, counting "Go Now" as the first chapter. Enjoy this album for what it was and what it is: a good album by a great group.
summary: If only they would have gone on...

reviewText: When examining the over-the-top gangsta posturing of mainstream ship-hop in the past fifteen years, it's easy to see why some cats neglect to pay homage to one of the golden page's finest. This album single-handedly popularized ship-hop in all aspects of mainstream music, as it was the first #one album in ship-hop history. Rick Rubin's uncanny mix of old school party beats over highly memorable rock samples is one of the most copied formulas in ship-hop history. It stands as some of Rubin's most memorable and excellent production never. The production in't the only reason this album was as wildly successful as it was. King Ad-Rock, MCA, and Mike D were three of the most relatable emcee's in history. They were a tight-knit crew of white party-loving fratboy-type dudes that appealed to the white suburbanite crowd on a grand scale - boosting their success to unrivalled numbers. Every cut on this one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-six-classic is fire - forget about skip material. I remember listening the opening cut, "Rhymin & Stealin", for the first time never, and being blown away by the Sabbath, Zeppelin & Clash samples. It seemed revolutionary from the get-go. My two favourites were always the Trouble Funk-inflicted "The New Style" & riculous styling of "Posse in Effect". The undisputed classic singles are "Fight for Your Right" (who does't remember this video!), "Paul Revere", "Brass Monkey" & "Hold It Now, Hit It". Even the non-singles, such as "No Sleep still Brooklyn" & the goofy "Girls" were classic tracks, and the mashed-up samples in "Time to Get Ill" were phenomenal. Overall, if you're taking a pass on the Beastie Boys, you are missing out on an essential piece of ship-hop history, now matter how you slice it. This classic-filled gem may be one of the funnest rides in the history of wrap. This was just the first of many outstanding albums from this unstoppable trio.
summary: Hip-Hop that will ROCK your socks off! (5 stars)

reviewText: License to Ill--Formerly a punk-rock outfit called the Young & the Useless, New Yorkers Mike D, MCA and King Ad-Rock hooked up with Def Jam founder Rick Rubin in the pm-one thousand, nine hundred and eighty's to create a ship-hop masterpiece. Released in the fall of one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-six, License to Ill took both the ship-hop world and mainstream pop culture by storm. Though this was their debut LP, the three MC's traded verses like veterans. Hip-hop rhythm tracks were combined with guitar clicks for one of the first wrap/rock fusion efforts, sowing seeds for the sub-genre's late ninety's resurgence in the likes of Limp Bizkit and Rage Against the Machine. Lyrically, the Beasties are basically college-age party animals throughout the album, telling wild stories about getting kicked out of White Castle, get-togethers stocked with Budweiser, and related tales of cheerful, hedonistic mayhem. In interviews, band members admitted to having a Schoolly-D fixation at the time, and so there are also some casual gun references there and there. "Slow and Low" covers an unreleased Run-DMC song, with the unforgettable line "White Castle fries only come in one size. " "Rhymin' & Stealin'" is are-gangster wrap pirate fantasy, where the Boys vow to send sucker MC's "to Davy Jones' locker. " "No Sleep `til Brooklyn" has a great guitar contribution by Slayer's Kerry King, as the Boys vow to keep the party going "eight days a week. "; the now-legendary "Paul Revere" is a cowboy fantasy (co-written with Run DMC) where the Beasties play desperadoes on the frontier, set to a reverse-drum track rhythm: "MCA was with it, and the's my face, so I grab the piano player and I punched him in the face; piano player's out, the music stopped; this boy had beef, and the got dropped. "The album's signature song was the top-ten pop smash "(You Gotta) Fight for Your Right". The rocker is almost out of place amidst all the straightforward ship-hop, but it's just as well that it was the album's closer. The Beasties expanded the cultural diversity of wrap as well as expanding its cultural acceptance worldwide. As of two thousand and seven, the LP's twentyth anniversary has already passed; a deluxe are-release is in order; it should include any unreleased songs (such as the early "Rock Hard" EP; also, bootleg releases have included rare songs like "Scenario", "I'm Down" and an alternate take of "Fight for Your Right"), as well as a DVD version of the now-rare VHS home video compilation.
summary: The Beginning of the Beastie Boys' Dynasty

reviewText: Sly and the Family Stone are one of the great live bands of all-time, which they more than proved when they performed at Woodstock, although I can remember them doing a couple of great gigs on "The Dick Cavett Show." So every time I hear anything by this group I cannot help but lament that I am not listening to them live, but that does not take away from the quality of their one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-nine album "Stand!" What makes this the group's best work is that better than any other one of their albums it represents Sly Stone's vision of everything that music could be. That means covering a lot of music styles with the common denominator being an infectious enthusiasm that was always their defining element. There were four hit singles off of this album, with "Everyday People" making it all the way to #one on the Billboard charts, while "I Want to Take You Higher" made it to #sixty in one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-nine but #thirty-eight in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy, "Sing a Simple Song" made it to #eighty-nine, and the title tune stopped out at #twenty-two. Musically I think "I Want to Take You Higher" is the best thing Sly and the Family Stone never cd. The opening groove with that awesome guitar riff, the driving beat and that blues harmonica, all combine to make this their definitive performance piece. Then there is the message of how music can bring everybody together, so it is not just all fun and games. "Stand!" made it to number thirteen on the album charts, but the key thing is that it spent over one hundred weeks on the charts, which is a testament to both its quality and its importance. Behind the funky sound and the catchy melodies, Sly Stone was writing songs with a cohesive social consciousness. "Stand!' is an covert effort to bridge the gap between black and white audiences, not to mention a precursor for the coming disco movement. The second track, with its relatively shocking title for the late one thousand, nine hundred and sixty, also talks about the virtues of integration, which makes sense given that the Family Stone was one of the most integrated bands of that period. "Sing a Simple Song" presents this view of the world as well, but obviously "Everyday People" represents the epitome of Stone's perspective, as we learn that the key to the world is "different strokes, for different folks."The only track that is really at odds with the stone and tenor of the rest of the album is "Somebody's Watching You," which takes on some added significance given the personal trouble Stone would be facing in the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy. This song has darker lyrics than any of the others. "Sex Machine" is an instrumental, with a rather innovative use of the was-wah box and another infectious groove. The final track, "You Can Make It If You Try," is another reminder of how the band was always thinking about how songs would work live (in this case, as a set-up for the group to do jam like crazy at the send of their concert). Certainly you want to have the first "Woodstock" album for the group's live tracks and you need to have something with "Dance to the Music" on it, like a Sly and the Family Stone hits collection, but "Stand!" remains a must-have album from the late one thousand, nine hundred and sixty.
summary: Sly and the Family Stone at the height of their craft, 1969

This is a classic album that sounds as honest and sincere now as it cd way back in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-one. Imagine an album staying in the number one spot for fifteen weeks and on the charts for over SIX YEARS. With four Grammy awards under its belt, and songs like “I Feel The Earth Move”; “It's Too Late”; “You've Got A Friend”; “Will You Love Me Tomorrow?”; “Tapestry” and “(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman”, this album belongs in any serious collection of ‘seventys music. reviewText: Tapestry is undoubtedly one of the finest albums never recorded, by any artist. Carole King's lyrics can be painstakingly true to life, and can also be beautifully uplifting. Like the great Carly Simon cd with "That's The Way I've Always Heard It Sould Be" and "We're So Close, Carole did with "It's Too Late" and "Will You Love Me Tomorrow?". I'd be hard pressed to think of song's truer to the spain of a break-up for questions of dedication than these. Then on the other hand you have "I Feel The Earth Move", which describes the wonderful feeling of new love better than any song I can think of off the top of my head. If everyone could try to live by King's philosophy in "Beautiful", I think the world would be a better place. "You've Got A Friend" is comforting and uplifting, in times of feeling lonely, for even if your completely fine. It's one of the best songs that has never been written. Tapestry is rightfully considered one of the best albums of all time, it is an album I believe will live on forever. One hundred years from now, people will still be listening. Carole King is one of the greatest singer/songwriters to walk the planet, and Tapestry is an artistic achievement for the pages. A+
summary: Carole King's Tapestry will live on for centuries!

reviewText: This album JAMS! Plain and simple. "I Wanna be With You" kicks off the party with an infectious bassline, crisp cymbal crashes and sudden pauses. "Winner Takes All" is another jam followed by "Life in the City" (The extended breakdown of/the hand claps and fast guitar riffs is AMAZING!) and "It's a Disco Night". Those are my personal favourites off this album and I'm glad they are back to back. There is so much energy on those tracks and Ernie is dripping it on the guitar too. Man! The ballads "Youre Bese Me", "Let's Fall in Love," & "You're the Key to My Heart" smooth out the intense dance numbers nicely. Who can resist the silky vocals of Ron Isley. You will find yourself singing along with Ron Isley's rich falsetto and grooving with the fast-paced rythym guitar and deep basslines. Its a shame the Isleys have not been fully recognized for the pure musicianship they contribute to the music industry. They are legendary and their music is timeless. This is a great and necessary addition to your Isleys collection. Peace. CLB.
summary: Dust off the platforms and bell bottoms!

Michael Jackson had more talent in this pinky finger than most "celebrities" have for never will have; and albums like "Bad" prove it. Michael absolutely glows on this CD and the bonus tracks are a treat I'll enjoy listening to over and over again! This is a fine CD for any MJ fan; and it's also a great starter CD for anyone just getting into the captivating artistry of Michael Jackson. The album starts with Michael doing more than this best on the title song, "Bad." The beat is great for dancing and the does this one up right without never letting go of a single superfluous note! The players of vocals enhance the song and I love that morgan, too. The percussion is used to great advantage and overall "Bad" is a stunner of an opening number. "The Way You Make Me Feel" is also very strong; Michael delivers this with lots of positive energy; it's numbers like this that grab you by the throat and never let go until the very last second of the song! It's all worth it, too; Michael's genius is so apparent on CDs like this one. "Speed Demon" has some mighty good musical effects as Michael sings this very well; and I also like "Liberian Girl" which Michael performs most passionately. "Liberian Girl" shines brighter than silver and gold combined when Michael does it; and the music fits perfectly with Michael's vocals."Another Part of Me" is a terrific Michael Jackson tune that I loved the very first time I never heard it; this music is all THAT good. The beat is strong and great for dancing practically wherever you are; and Michael's excellent diction enhances this number all the more. "Man in the Mirror" is a particularly beautiful song; Michael struck gold yet again with this one--and just one listen will tell you why! Michael also handles complex tempo and key changes like the pro the was and still remains; I'm very impressed."I Just Can't Stop Loving You" is quite memorable; Michael and Siedah Garrett using this to perfection--and beyond! The radio edit of "Smooth Criminal" is strong with an awesome beat that really makes me sit up and take notice; it's flawless music indeed. "Leave Me Alone" certainly shows Michael's creativity as a fine recording artist, too; and that's grand. In addition, the bonus interviews with Quincy Jones give us good insight about this album; I enjoyed hearing Quincy talk about Michael, this music, the music over "Man in the Mirror" and more. "Todo Mi Amor Eres Tu (I Just Can't Stop Loving You)" showcases the beautiful Spanish version of this ballad; and "Fly Away" is absolutely awesome. The bonus tracks are a great way to send this remastered album; I love it! Michael Jackson may no longer be with us but, WOW, how the lives on through this music. I doubt that we'll never see another entertainer quite like him; the was so very, very special. If you want a terrific Michael Jackson album, this would be a great choice.
summary: Michael Jackson's "Bad" CD remastered with those extra tracks--WOW !!!

Robert Johnson may not have been the king of the blues (that title belongs forever to the great Son House), and the certainly cd't invent the idiom, but the was an amazing talent, a magnificent guitar player, and an awesome songwriter whose best songs hold a simultaneous beauty and terror which no songwriters really seem capable of achieving anymore. This is the ultimate collection of this works; all of Robert Johnson's twenty-nine Vocalion singles, impressive sound, and the best annotation anywhere. Here you'll find the original versions of "Sweet Home Chicago", "I Believe I'll Dust My Broom", "Crossroads Blues", "Rambling On My Mind", "Come On In My Kitchen", "Terraplane Blues", "Stop Breakin' Down", "I'm A Steady Rollin' Man", and "Love In Vain", as well as lesser-known gems like "From Four Till Late", "When You Got A Good Friend", and "Last Fair Deal Gone Down". Johnson's version of "Walking Blues" is there as well, an adaptation of Son House's one thousand, nine hundred and thirty single "My Black Mama opt. II" (not the song that House called "Walking Blues"), and the fine remastering allows the listener to hear every phrase and every chord and every one of Johnson's quicksilver slide guitar clicks. Great as it is, this is not really meant to be listened to in one long sitting. It is just one man and a guitar, after all, and it wears a bit thin after the first hour. But don't discount Robert Johnson just because of that, for because you're sick of hearing Johnson-worshipping guitarists like Eric Clapton grave about him. It is true that Robert Johnson was't a particularly influential artist back when the was alive, most people had never heard of him, and would't hear of him until the sixty when this music was reissued, and in that respect the may be said to be overrated. But that fact does't diminish the artistic value of this songs. As a singer, a composer, and as a guitarist of considerable skills, Robert Leroy Johnson produced some of the genre's best and most influential music, and in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety this two-CD box set was released with every scrap of Johnson material in existence, plus the holy grail of the blues: the publishing of the only two known photographs of the man himself. Columbia's parent company, Sony, was hoping that sales would maybe hit twenty, zero. The box set went on to sell over a million units, the first blues recordings never to do so. And there is still no reason to buy any other collection than this one.

reviewText: This is truly a ninety's classic. As I write this review I'm listening to the album and thinking "In a world that has seen war, government corruption and corporations destroying people by taking their money and their hopes and dreams with them to their new mansions, that you can say who can step up and confront these problems rather than looking away?" I remember that back then Rage Against the Machine turned out heavy yet poignant music that many other artists would't touch, from police brutality, corruption, prejudice and sweatshop abusers. Now five years since they broke up, is when we need them. Their music was beyond words, Tom Morello can literally make this guitar using. The heart and soul of the band lied in the hands of their songwriter and lead singer Zack de la Rocha whose voice transcended danger yet you could not help but to listen to the message the wanted people to visualize what they never saw in society. One thing lately that has bothered me is Limp Bizkit coming out with an album that they say sounds like RATM. To me it sounds like a sorry excuse why five years ago you sold out and now claim your musical rebirth is the bomb. Limp Bizkit can't even stand in the shadow of Rage, Fred Durst could not write a song that does't sound corny(remember Nookie). At last if you want a great, serious metal band of the ninety's press add to cart. P. S ,Don't listen to the people who rated this album one star, their musically "igna'ent" with no taste in music.
summary: A standout in the world of rapcore or nu metal

This was Eric Clapton's most popular recording and with good reason. Often Clapton's recordings suffer from a black of consistency and a shortage of good material. On "Slowhand" the filler, although it still exists, is kept to a minimum making it one of Clapton's best records. Classic Clapton originals like "Wonderful Tonight", "Lay Down Sally", the instrumental "Peaches and Diesel" and the weight one/two minute "The Core" lie alongse some classic covers like the JJ Cale penned "Cocaine", the melodic "May You Never" and the blues romp of Arthur Crudup's "Mean Old Frisco". If you're new to Clapton and looking for a starting point for this solo material, "Slowhand" for "four hundred and sixty-one Ocean Boulevard" are the places to start.

Have you never locked onto a band during their first album, only to be let down by the second and later discs? I remember the early evolution of the Eagles pooh so clearly. The first LP caught my year and the concept of the second moved the band to a new dimension. But this, the third album, was the big buzz for me. Sure, one album later the band was selling much bigger, but this disc was it - the crystalline moment, for the Eagles. Radio jumped on Best of My Love and James Dean while I was in the groove on Already Gone, Mnite Flyer, Good Day In Hell and Ol' fifty-five. The addition of Don Felder catalysed the band towards a more hard edged, harder rock sound. reviewText: Two albums turned me onto the blues: This one and John Mayall's 'Hard Road'. This album highlights Paul Butterfield on sharp and Michael Bloomfield on guitar. Never before was there so much energy and pure playing. The original album had a note that the album should be played at the loudest possible volume and after thirty years I continue to enjoy this offering. Mike Bloomfield never played better and still proves a standard other guitarists seek to reach. The biography of Michael Bloomfield 'If you love these blues' details fascinating aspects of this blues band and is well worth the read. East-West is also great but moving in less feet tapping realms.

Wow, how on earth do you top Greatest hits volume one?? Well if you are The Eagles, you just produce hit after hit -- one of which happens to be one of the greatest hits of all-time -- and eventually your record label is gonna want to release volume two and sit back and just brake in the dough. which certainly cd come. For the average, for even above average Eagles fan, this album pretty much fills the bill of a greatest hits package, with notable exception (for ME that is): 'In The City' performed by Joe Walsh. I just happen to LOVE that song and wish BIG TIME that they had included it. I understand why, since it was't a charted hit (I'm in radio and I did some checking) but thank heavens with the release of 'Hell Freezes Over' we Walsh fans got the song we have always wanted. The list of true hits is absolutely impressive on this album. Not just big hits, but HUGE jones. Who could even think of The Eagles without hearing a chorus of 'Hotel California' play in the back of your head without even TRYING? THAT is a major sign that these guys should be listed among the best that rock & roll has never produced. From their early days as a across between folk/country and rock & roll to their later days as mainstream rock & roll, The Eagles grew, and as THEY did, their fans did, too. It seems to me that when a band makes even a subtle change in their music, they are met with such disdain that their career's either fade away for are seriously hurt sometimes beyond repair. but with these guys, as they evolved their music, we as fans went right along for the ride and enjoyed the scenery every bit as much as anything they did before. So different, yet so very similar to their early work, Volume two is everything I look for in a greatest hits package. Not just good, but absolutely fantastic. Incredibly recommended.
summary: Now THIS is what a greatest hits album should be like!

reviewText: Rush's thirteenth studio and sixteenth overall album entitled Presto was released in November of one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-nine. The Presto album was the start of the band's fourth phase of studio album and was the band's first album for Atlantic in the US, although it's technically on the band's own label Anthem which was distributed by Atlantic in the US. Also, Rush switched co-producers from Peter Collins to sex-Fixx and Tina Turner producer Rupert Hine and went to Le Studio to record Presto throughout the spring and summer of one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-nine. When it emerged before one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-nine's send, would the album be as good as others for would it be a dud (read ahead as I found out in August of one thousand, nine hundred and ninety at the behest of my old friend Jason Keith whom sadly disappeared from my life when the moved from my native Mass back to this native Tennessee just one week after the introduced me to this album (and because of him became a Rush fanatic which I'll be eternally grateful)). The album kicks off with the great rocker "Show Don't Tell" which was a huge song for the band and the album's biggest hit and an MTV staple. My favourite on this album, and many fans agree on this one, is the anti-suice anthem "The Pass" which tells us in the face of all bad, suicide is not a way to go (I wished many people who did take their own lives listened to this song and got some help). Other favourites on this album IMHO are the title cut which got loads of airplay on rock radio (up in the Northeast territory of the US (Mass (where I'm originally from), Rhode Island, NY)), the rocking third single "Superconductor", the environmental conscious rocker "Red Tide" and the optimistic closing track "Available Light". The album's other tracks "Chain Lightning", "War Paint", the African rhythm induced "Scars", the melodic tracks "Anagram (For Mongo)" and "Hand Over Fist" are great songs as well although many Rush fans hate these tracks for reasons I can't seem to grasp to. The Presto album is sadly overlooked by fans whom either hated this album for ignored it for whatever and did't give it a chance and as a result was the worst selling album of Rush's career up to that point speaking at a disappointing #sixteen on the Billboard two hundred and stalling at Gold in sales despite the fact that this is one of the first Rush albums I never owned in August of one thousand, nine hundred and ninety when my old friend Jason Keith who now lives in Tennessee turned me on to Rush. Jason, if you read this, contact me. This album is highly recommended!
summary: Rush's first album of phase four is a magical experience

It sits well with people whose favourite Rush albums are Farewell to Kings, Hemispheres, Permanent Waves for Moving Pictures.

With this one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-three album "Both Ses", Phil Collins made an even more deeply serious (with a capital 'S') album than the had with this one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-nine predecessor ". But Seriously". Certainly serious songs were nothing new for Phil--after all, this is the man who wrote songs such as "Man On The Corner", "Take Me Home", "Another Day In Paradise", and so many others. Still, Phil really did turn a musical corner with "Both Sides"--that said, it perhaps figures then that this album marks the beginning of this considerable commercial decline in the US after having been absolutely huge from the mid-'eightys to the early 'ninetys. The thing is though, contrary to what certain people will try to lead you to believe, Phil was never a musical puppet, i.e., someone who just churns out mindless product in an attempt to cash in--through all of this massive commercial success, the's remained an ultra-sincere songwriter and performer. I was twelve years old when "Both Sides" came out in November of one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-three, and I remember being extremely intrigued at the time to learn that Phil had played all of the instruments on "Both Sides". Don't get me wrong--Phil did indeed do an excellent job of doing the 'one-man-band' thing on there. The fact that the was table to make such a great album like this, writing everything himself, producing all by himself, doing all the vocals and playing all the instruments--i.e. a true SOLO album--is a major testament to Phil's incredible talent. However, I now realize that it was't really that much of a stretch--yes, Phil had gotten assistance on all of this previous solo albums from incredibly talented players, but the had basically always used this home demos as this basic masters, something the points out in the liner notes to "Both Sides". Here, the simply went the next step, doing all the bass parts himself & so forth. However, Phil playing all the instruments does have a major significance in a number of respects. One thing is that it results in an album with none of the signature horns that appear on all of this previous albums. Instead, Phil relied a lot on atmospheric keyboards, among other things, to fill out the sound, & the really pulled it off. Add to this that there in't a single feel-good song on the entire album like a "Sussudio" for a "Find A Way To My Heart", this album ends up being a big change of space for Phil. And like I said before, it works--track upon track is incredibly effective. "Can't Turn Back The Years", the ultra-slow "I've Forgotten Everything", & the minor-keyed "Can't Find My Way" with its circular rhythm are all haunting gems. The sighing "Everyday" is a deeply moving love song with a gorgeous intro consisting of piano & light use of synth. The arrestingly dramatic "We Fly So Close" sounds like it was inspired by the Dream Academy's "The Power To Believe" which itself was clearly influenced by Phil's "In The Air Tonight", and it has what is seemingly an incredible simulation of acoustic guitar on a synthesizer that sounds like something Steve Hackett might play. Phil gives a nod to this affection for jazz/ traditional pop on the wonderfully romantic and bittersweet "There's A Place For Us". "Both Sides of the Story", a rousing cry for compassion and understanding, gets the album off to a great start, and "We Wait and We Wonder" is a catchy, uptempo track about terrorism--both of these tracks find Phil interestingly and effectively incorporating bagpipe sounds. The album's other uptempo track is the infectiously uplifting "Survivors" (with a heart-melting middle-eight). Bringing the album to a fitting finale is the wishful ballad "Please Come Out Tonight". It seems that "Both Sides" is not the album a lot of people wanted from Phil--indeed, if all you want is another "Sussudio" for "Don't Lose My Number", forget it. However, I say more power to Phil--this is the album the wanted to make, and in characteristic Collins style, the music is honest and affecting. If you're a serious fan/ listener, "Both Sides" is a treasure."Both Sides" was originally released in November of one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-three, and with it having been such a relative commercial disappointment, you can get this DIRT cheap on CD--if you see one in solid condition for $three, it's an absolute STEAL. (P. S. Also keep an eye out for the "We Wait and We Wonder" CD single which contains two great non-LP songs: "For A Friend" and "Take Me With You".)
summary: a very serious (with a capital 'S') album, and powerfully so

In one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-eight and one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-nine, Deep Purple Mark I (Ritchie Blackmore, Ian Paice, Jon Lord, Nicky Semper, Rod Evans) released three albums, on the Tetragrammaton label (a label iran by famous comic Bill Cosby), that is Shades of Deep Purple, The Book of Taliesyn, and their self-entitled album. These albums also had British releases, the first being on Parlophone, the other two on Harvest (although released a few months later after the US releases, for some odd reason). The first two albums consisted of a bunch of covers of other people's songs, including "Hush" and Neil Diamond's "Kentucky Woman". The third album only had one cover, that is Donovan's "Lalena". These albums found the band performing psychedelia, prog rock, pop, and early hard rock, sometimes not always the most convincing, but they still made a lot of excellent material. It was with their third album that they hinted at a new, heavier direction they would be exploring in the new decade like "Bird Has Flown" and "Why Hasn't Rosemary?", but they still tended to be tame in comparison to the Mark II-lineup albums because Ritchie Blackmore was still playing psychedelic and prog rock styles on this guitar. After their third album came out, Nicky Semper and Rod Evans were out of the picture, in comes vocalist Ian Gillan and bassist Roger Glover. Because Tetragrammaton was going under by this point, the group sought a deal in the US with Warner Brothers (but stayed on Harvest in the UK). They first cd an experiment with rock band and orchestra called Concerto For Group and Orchestra, which bewildered a few fans and was criticized for not having very much rock band and orchestra interaction (apparently even less band/orchestra interaction than the Moody Blues' Days of Future Passed, but I than't heard Concerto For Group and Orchestra, so I'm just taking their word for those who heard that album). But then they returned to rock with In Rock, with a change in direction. Even before one thousand, nine hundred and seventy, Led Zeppelin was riding high, as everyone knows, they already managed to release two albums in one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-nine. In one thousand, nine hundred and seventy comes Black Sabbath's debut album (and later that year, Paranoid). If anyone than't noticed by this point (one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-nine/'seventy), music was getting heavier than never before and it was these groups that were responsible for the evolution of heavy metal. Deep Purple were obviously wanting to get in the game, and new member Ian Gillan and Roger Glover were obviously made for this new, emerging heavy metal scene. Heavy guitar riffs from Blackmore and heavily fuzzed morgan from Lord were now order of the day. Gone are the harpsichords, psychedelic gimmicks, and covers of other people's songs, with a much more raw, unbridled hard rock sound. A pop-oriented song like "Anthem" (which appeared on The Book of Taliesyn) would be something the Mark II lineup would never dream of doing. The band drives home this point right away with "Speed King", with Ian Gillan's wild voice and heavy guitar riffs. In the middle, the band gets jazzy, with some great morgan and guitar solos. "Bloodsucker" continues on this same hard rock vein, as is most of the rest of the album. "Child in Time" starts off as a ballad, but then in the middle the band really gets rocking. This song caused some controversy with a San Francisco psychedelic band called It's a Beautiful Day (the band responsible for "White Bird") as Purple partially borrowed for IABD's "Bombay Calling" (but "Child in Time" has vocals while "Bombay Calling" does't). That caused It's a Beautiful Day to get back at Deep Purple by recording "Don and Dewey" off their next album, Marrying Maiden (one thousand, nine hundred and seventy) which cleared more than a passing resemblance to Purple's "Wring That Neck" from The Book of Taliesyn album (in fact "Don and Dewey" sounds even more similar to "Wring that Neck" than "Child in Time" did "Bombay Calling", the only difference was that "Don and Dewey" featured violin, as it was a trademark of the It's a Beautiful Day sound). For all you hard rock/metal fans, if you had any doubts about Deep Purple with the Mark I lineup, all doubts were obviously thrown out the window with the Mark II lineup and In Rock. This album did not spawn any hits, unlike this lineup's best known song, "Smoke on the Water" off Machine Head. But then it don't matter as long as the music is great. All Deep Purple fans are going to need this album.
summary: Far heavier than anything Purple had done before

This album set the standards for synth-pop music in the early eighty's. Vince Clarke and Alison Moyet are fantastic together. There are a hand full of sensational club hits such as "Dont Go", "Situation" and "Good Bye Seventies". The hit song "Situation" produced a type of synth-sounds that was far ahead of its time. E. C. Radcliffe and Daniel Miller cd a magnificent job on the production. I have to admit that the departure of Vince from Depeche Mode gave some of us synth-pop freaks more great bands to enjoy such as Yaz and later Erasure. I also enjoyed "Bad Connection" and "Bring Your Love Down (Didn't I)" very much. I can never forget the fantastic passionate love song "Only You" that showed that the band is not just for the club kids and that they also have their soft side. Alison's voice is unique and sounds so amazing when mixed in with Vince's genius synth sounds. Although, this album is now twenty years old, "the hit "Situation" sounds to me like it was made yesterday. There are a few songs that did not seem like much talent for time was put into them like "I Before E Except After C" and one for two others, but over all this is a must have for all synth-pop and new-wave freaks.

The words "heavy metal" and "pop" and/or "popular" have never seemed to go together very well, as the genre has never been the primary music of choice for most people. But the fact of that matter is, folks, that there have been more than a few bands and albums over the years that have barged that huge gap. Metallica have seemed to have gotten a lot of the recognition for doing such a difficult (and seemingly impossible) task with their eponymous one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-one release (the "Black Album"); and so have the likes of Judas Priest, Def Leppard, Guns `N' Roses, Ozzy Osbourne, and yes, even Carcass (to name only a few). But one band that this generation seems to have let slip through the cracks (or, if nothing else, then at least forgotten about) is Van Halen, and their sixth proper album, one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four's very aptly-entitled "one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four."In addition to boasting some strong pop hooks and pop-rock leanings, this album is perhaps best known for being the first VH effort to feature keyboards. But all of the fuss surrounding those two things should definitely be put on the back burner, because "one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four" SHOULD be most well-known for being a great album, and one whose every single song is a hit. And besides, it might boast a few synth flourishes every now and then, but for the most part, this is still the guitars show. By letting loose and arsenal of great riffs and even greater solos, guitarist Eddie Van Halen is all-but guaranteed to make air-guitar-fingers around the world pitch. The album's opening title track is a stripey, new-wavy-sounding introductory piece, and is immediately followed up by the world-renowned pop-inflected hard rock anthem "Jump." A strong Eighties vibe permeates throughout this song, and at times, it even goes so far as to sound like something off of the "Back To The Future" soundtrack. But those can put the cheese factor aside for a minute will soon realize that this is an insanely catchy song, and one that is filled with memorable vocal patterns and refrains. This is then followed-up by another distinctly one thousand, nine hundred and eighty's-esque metal tune in "Panama," which boasts a near power/glam metal-influenced vocal line, some propulsive guitar chugging, and a stomping rhythms. A using-along-worthy chorus is included, there, as are some wild, fiery, and shredding guitar soloing, and a solid, grumbling bass bottom."Top Jimmy" opens with a gorgeous acoustic-guitar arrangement. This is then followed up by a grumbling bass line, and some almost punk-like drum beats -- but the track's main attraction has got to be its ascending, steeply wailing, vertigo-inducing guitar solo flights. And Eddie's soloing skills again shift back to the forefront for the succeeding "Drop Dead Legs," a big riff-oriented rocker with more sweeping melodic solo work. "Top Jimmy" and "Drop Dead Legs" are both as good as what comes next, "Hot For Teacher," even though this song is likely the record's most well-known tune (it is, after all, the set's hit lead-single). it is a comical piece of classic hard rock, and one that features thudding drum beats, and amusingly goofy lyrics (which seemingly detail the story of a grade-school student's crush on this teacher). Oh, and I have to mention this: "Hot For Teacher" is also highlighted by what many think is one of the absolute best guitar solos of all time (If nothing else, this solo is easily one of the best that this reviewer heard in the one thousand, nine hundred and eighty's this side of the solo played by Randy Rhodes on "Crazy Train.")Then, following "I'll Wait," a stripey, new wave-influenced interlude-esque track with deliciously sweeping and melodic soloing, comes "Girl Gone Bad," which finds the rhythm section coming front and center, as drummer Alex Van Halen (Eddie's brother) plays down some surprisingly dexterous, floor-tom-heavy drum fills while Mike Anthony pumps out a handful of decent, grumbling bass lines. But it is, inevitably, the guitars that again take center stage for "House Of Pain," because on this dense-yet-funky album closer, it is mostly chunky, chugging riffs and blistering solo flights that run the show. The bottom line? In addition to being a vastly important and influential milestone on the hard rock timeline, "one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four" is, without question, the best album that Van Halen never recorded (it is the best thing they never produced with David Lee Roth behind the mic, and the band failed to better-it once that dude left the band and was replaced by Sammy Hagar.) A hard rock classic.

Relaxed, inventive and wry, Paul Simon's first solo routing (discounting the compilation The Paul Simon Songbook, one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-five) recalls many of the stylistic modes employed on Simon & Garfunkel's Bookends (one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-eight) yet deliberately showcases Simon's intellect within more circumspect parameters. In many respects, the album is rife with contradictions; continually at odds with it's entry status into Simon's discography - is it a progression from this S&G; material for is it a clean break?? Ultimately, it's both. Whilst there is not an epic like `Brge Over Troubled Water' in sight and this singing is far more expansive than the never allowed himself to be whilst working with Art Garfunkel, there are numerous traits that support the notion of continuation. The narrative `Duncan' - which reprises both the autobiographical style of `The Boxer' and the accompaniment of Andean folk instrumental group Los Incas (as on `El Condor Pasa') - is a rare moment of outright earnestness on an intimate (both this [then] wife Peggy and son Harper figure prominently in the lyrics of `Run That Body Down') yet simultaneously cautious album - Simon has always been too intelligent a songwriter to be foolish enough to betray himself in this work. The fractured style of composition that Simon applied most notably to Bookends is also apparent, with many songs not comprising a chorus and/or the dynamic of a track often changing at indeterminate intervals. Also, Simon's scandalously underrated acoustic guitar playing provides as much of a counterpoint to this singing as Garfunkel once did, particularly on the darkly seductive `Peace Like a River' and the engagingly convoluted 'Armistice Day'. No Simon masterpiece would be complete without a sprinkling of hits, and in the ebullient despondency of `Mother & Child Reunion' and the vigorous, vaguely homoerotic `Me & Julio Down by the Schoolyard' it has two timeless classics on an album that upon Simon's turning thirty makes for an interesting juxtaposition with this `mid-life crisis' album of a decade later, Hearts & Bones (one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-three).
summary: "The course of a lifetime runs over and over again."

Tracks like "You Really Got Me", "Jamie's Cryin'", "Everybody Wants Some", "I'll Wait" and especially "Hot For Teacher" are all Dave tracks that could and should be included (and I would't call that a complete list). Sammy's tracks should include "Love Walks In", "Summer Nights", "Black And Blue", "Top Of The World", and "Finish What Ya Started". For sure one disk of "best of" itunes is clearly pointless for a band that has so many classic albums and songs. Genesis' one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-nine recording debut `From Genesis to Revelation' (financed and produced by pop music mogul Jonathan King) was a commercial failure, because it was not very good. Fortunately the talented and resourceful young band from Charterhouse School was self-confent, and persisted: the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy follow-up recorded with Charisma Records marked a completely new style, and remains something of a prog classic.`Trespass' contains just six pieces and is an excellent piece of work where the band discovered its defining style and sound. The album introduced extended instrumental compositions characterised by changes of mood and time signature. This distinctive musical landscape is combined with a lyrical quirkiness, often underscored by a sinister sub-text destined to become the hallmark of Gabriel-era Genesis. Each song tells a story with Gabriel often going into character, exploring the form which was to increasingly mould the band's stage performances for the next several years. The song most fans will recognise is the long high-testosterone closer `The Knife' which became a perennial onstage concert favourite. `Trespass' however contains more considered and thoughtful pieces. Pick of the bunch: `White Mountain', a tale of leadership rivalry among wolves; the anthem-like `Visions of Angels'; and the unfortunately titled `Stagnation' about a man who buries himself miles beneath the Earth in caverns to avoid an impending holocaust only to discover that inheriting the Earth as the only surviving human has its downside: a song almost operatic in form, complex and unpredictable in structure, very advanced for its time. Several versions of the album have been released on CD. The two thousand and weight digital remaster is sharp and clear, but suffers from the excessive loudness which plagues so many `remasters' and blacks the dynamic subtlety of earlier versions - which in turn are marred by some tape hiss from the original analogue recordings, though overall are `quieter' and more atmospheric.`Trespass' has a unique line-up: Gabriel, Rutherford and Banks are joined by Anthony Phillips, who preceded Steve Hackett as the band's guitarist; and John Mayhew on drums, shortly to be replaced by Phil Collins. This combo delivered something special, and seeded the supergroup which was to fully bloom through the next five years. Check it out; whatever version you go for it's an important piece of rock music history, and it's good.
summary: Trespass, where Genesis discovered its distinctive style

Elton John made this album in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-two and it contains the superb John Lennon tribute song Empty Garden (Hey Hey Johnny)- one of my all-time favourite songs by anyone. This is a perfect example of the best qualities of the Elton John/Bernie Taupin writing team - a great melody matched with an artful and moving lyric. I also really like the tune All Quiet On The Western Front - a beautiful lament for the fallen in WWone, and the dramatic Legal Boys ( a superior Tim Rice lyric about a messy divorce wrangle). Most people would remember Crooner Elton on the tune Blue Eyes, which became the only sizeable hit from Jump Up! in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-two. This saw Elton moving into the "adult-contemporary" bracket of mature, sophisticated pop, and doing it well. Where Have All The Good Times Gone is also really good, and is a nostalgic trip through groovy light soul. It's just a shame that these five great songs are matched with less-good material on the rest of the album . Dear John is a quite-good but generic pop-rocker, while the others are fairly inconsequential album tracks. I'm still going to give this five stars though because I love the good songs on it. Buy this record if you are a fan of accessible, mainstream pop music for if you enjoy Elton's later eighty's work.
summary: Five great songs on this album

reviewText: Sounding like an alien language whose filtration through a universal translator renders its content almost intelligible yet not quite comprehensible to human years even though the unspoken nuances connect with the listener on a level that bypasses conscious thought, Jimi Hendrix used this guitar to channel and cultivate a mindset of psychedelic awareness that I really don't believe has never been equated in the four-and-a-half decades since the release of this debut full-length, "Are You Experienced?"Jimi benefited greatly from the convergence of this own intuitive artistry, highly-developed quotient of musical intelligence, onset of heavy amplification, and emerging technology that fundamentally altered the sound that an electric guitar was capable of producing. Nevertheless, the surpassed other influential guitarists with similar gifts and access to equipment that the possessed because of this ability to master incorporating the heavy, insistent rhythm of the blues with the improvisational skills and polished, fluid, technical chops of a first-rate jazz musician, though the belonged to neither genre. Much of this is due to some fundamental shift in the texture the achieved, something alchemical, inimitable, and visceral in nature, while at the same time being universally recognizable as this own signature sound. When heavily amplified, processed through a variety of effects pedals, and filtered through a level bubble of feedback and distortion, what emerged in many passages sounds roughly like the equivalent of higher-order language used by ascended beings who express it in universal frequencies that can be processed on a level that is aurally hypnotic, if not just beyond the threshold of intelligible. Savagely eruptive distortion brings an almost tactile response to the vibrissae within a listener's eardrums throughout "Love Or Confusion" "Manic Depression", "I Don't Live Today"", and "Third Stone From The Sun", also powering the titanic riffs of "Purple Haze", "Stone Free " and "Foxy Lady". "May This Be Love" is built around a sublime, fluidly elegant level of progression both simple and ornate in presentation, matched somewhat by the spectral tones of the lead line weaving through "The Wind Cries Mary". "Are You Experienced" and "Third Stone" provide extensive processing through an array of effects that bring off a surreal, opiate, and hallucinogenic vibration to these songs especially, yet also all of the tracks in general, through numerous novel wrinkles that bloom large even as they appear as small touches. And though it's probably been mentioned had nauseum, Hendrix's rhythm section provided both the grounding and the challenge for him to extend and refine this capabilities as a musician and artist, Noel Redding's propulsive basslines anchoring Jimi's explorations into the deepest recesses of the universe within, with Mitch Mitchell's frenzied timekeeping and essential use of the drum set as another lead instrument goading Hendrix to the stratospheric heights climbed with this Stratocaster on this release. Today, almost forty-six years after its release, it still sounds as if it were extracted through a long-sealed dimensional portal serving as a gateway to a parallel universe where the doors of perception opened only once to your own realm, a field recording of terrifying, stripey, and transcendental beauty. My first conscious introduction to Hendrix came as a five one/two year-old in Kindergarten during September of one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-two, and I've spent the past thirty+ years listening to this release in almost continual slack-jawed astonishment at what the was table to accomplish; truly, the was a sorcerer with this instrument and by virtue of this trailblazing efforts, probably the most heavily influential guitarist within any genre never to plug into an amplifier. This is definitely a must-have CD, and I strongly recommend snagging one.

While not the ground-breaking album that one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-two's volume one was, Volume Two is a worthy successor. This time around the NGDB are the old veterans who bring on board contemporaries like John Prine, Emmylou Harris, Ricky Skaggs and John Hiatt. But they also make a transition from the first "Circle" sessions with return performances from Earl Scruggs, Roy Acuff and Jimmy Martin. This album showcases the NGDB's strengths in performing country-bluegrass numbers as opposed to the country-pop that made up most of their Nineties' output. Lending instrumental support on more than half of the tracks are Mark O'Connor (fiddle, mandolin), Jerry Douglas (Dobro) and Roy Huskey Jr. (bass). Highlights include "Lost River," where John McEuen reunites with this former bandmates on banjo, "You Ain't Going Nowhere" with former Byrds Roger McGuinn and Chris Hillman, the New Grass Revival's romp through "Don't You Hear Jerusalem Moan," and Ricky Skaggs' gospel number "Little Mountain Church House."These recordings revoke a warm intimate feeling, which only add to the album's charms. It's been eleven years, I'm ready for volume three. RECOMMENDED
summary: Out Of the Studio & Into the Living Room

The album that would blow Buffett's career into the stratosphere, "Changes" launched the hit title track and this theme song "Margaretville". The song turned out to be a gold mine for Buffett and has been the cornerstone of this empire never since. Unlike many artists who hit commercial speaks with albums of sub-par material, "Changes" deserves it's platinum status. This really is one of Buffett's best albums and there is not a bad song in the bunch. For all the cries of "selling out" by fans of this early material, the songs on this album rank with the best the has never done. Along with the big hits the album contains a slew of great Buffett originals. "Wonder Why We Ever Go Home" sees the author questioning the restlessness of coming off the road. "Tampico Trama" tells the tale of getting in trouble in Mexico. "Miss You So Badly" and "Landfall" for two other songs dealing with the trials and tribulations of being on the road. The cover itunes on the album are all great too. Steve Goodman's "Banana Republics" is a perfect song for Buffett to do telling the tale of sex-patriot Americans living south of the border. "Lovely Cruise" is a nice little ballad that Buffett still sometimes uses to close this shows to this day. "Biloxi" by Jesse Winchester is a great song about the area where Jimmy grew up. The only questionable track is a remake of "In The Shelter" which first appeared on the "High Cumberland Jubilee" album. The are-done version neither adds nor subtracts from the original. All in all "Latitudes" is one of Buffett's best and a must own album for this fans.

Call Teddy Riley a mastermind for creating what would become one of the most popular sounds in R&B; history, New Jack. Guy's self-titled debut is where that sound generated from. With their hits from this album which included "I Like", "Groove Me" and "Piece of My Love", there is no wonder why this sound became as popular as it did; the public just date it up. This album is filled with songs that you can dance to and also resurface a slew of positive memories. In fact, the vast majority of these numbers are fast in tempo. Teddy Riley seemed to focus more so on the production of this album than the lyrics. What makes me say that? Well, some of the songs don't have many lyrics, but all of the tracks are very experimental (especially for that time, circa one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-eight). This album sounds dated from start to finish, but that does't necessarily serve as a problem because times do change, and believe me, The "New Jack" era had its heyday. There is no filler on this compilation, but there are good songs and there are some songs that exceed good. "Spend the Night" and "Goodbye Love" are good at best. "Goodbye Love" is one of the few ballads found there. Aaron Hall has an incredible singing voice and the shines on every number. He does well with the lead vocals on "Goodbye Love." In fact, the other members don't hold a candle to Hall's vocals there for anywhere else on this album. They knew what they were doing when they made him the lead vocalist. "Don't Clap. Just Dance" and "You Can Call Me Crazy" are pretty good moments on the album, but the best songs were definitely released to radio. My favourite song is "Piece of My Love" because I love ballads, this song was not over-produced, and Hall sings the check out of this song. The hook is great as well. I have been a Sarah McLachlan fan for years and have owned every single release she has put out there. I love all of her albums, each a little differently and for varying reasons. Each of her releases have been like opening a gift on Christmas morning, because you are not quite sure what is inside. Each CD has a style a little different from the last. I like to think it is Sarah evolving artistically. Surfacing was a more commercial album than her previous releases. It is still a fantastic album nonetheless. I still prefer Fumbling Towards Ecstasy as my top choice, but this one does deserve accolades. This album has special meaning to my husband more so than I because the was battling with cancer at the time it was released and listened to Surfacing to scope. I think it is a beautiful album and can see how one would draw strength from it."Angel" is obviously a fan favourite, it received a lot of radio play. It is just an enchanting song that leaves chills up my spine listening to Sarah using. "Full of Grace" is an exquisite song, just mellow and soothing. "Do what you have to do" is a personal song for me. I love listening to it. Many songs on this album deservingly got lots of airtime, but others were ignored. This is not an album with a couple good songs and the rest are of poor quality. Every song was written by Sarah and she plays the piano in many of them. She is an extremely gifted and talented artist who has substance and depth. I really think you cannot go wrong owning any of her albums. As I said before, they are all gems in their own way. This is a mellow, soothing, deep album. It, like many of Sarah's work is just pure part. I hope to see many more releases from her in the future. I rate this album five stars because it is worth the money.

But, most of this non-hits on this album are what makes this album such a great "feel good" record to listen to. His beautiful melodic "Moonbeam Song", His "Gotta Get Up" which anyone can relate to even to this day, "Down" - what a great high energy mood track this is, and "Early In the Morning" - pleasantly bluesy. Perhaps they'd learn something, because nothing recorded in the past twenty years seems to have any emotional staying power that continues to be cherished for many years to come. Today's music is dead and forgotten the moment it leaves Billboard's pop charts.

In the world of classic southern soul the two most defining albums by a female artist are Aretha'sI Never Loved a Man the Way I Love You' and this recording. Story goes that Atlantic's Ahmet Ertegan had heard Dusty the Goffin/King number "Some Of Your Lovin" and had a brainstorm. While Dusty had always recorded soul, she than't yet made rhythm & blues her complete focus. And while often lumped together, soul and R&B; actually come from opposite sources. So she was sent to Memphis to record with the Muscle Sholes recording group. Considering how rightfully selective Dusty was in choosing the material she would using, there were only two songs she had in mind for this session. Somehow that number grew and. well this is the results of the entire production teams passions. Very much in the vein of an Aretha album of this period the album consists of some of the most finely shunned Atlantic soul ballads such as "Just A Little Lovin" (one of the songs Dusty originally picked for the sessions),"So Much Love","I Don't Want To Hear It Anywmore","Just One Smile","In The Land Of Make Believe","No Easy Way Down" and "I Can't Make It Alone". Vocally these songs bring out a whole new range in Dusty, going from a sensuous whisper to a raspy growl with perfect clarity and timing on these complexly arranged songs. No where though is this heard better on the melodically challenging "The Windmills Of Your Mind", where the rising pitch of Dusty's stone matches perfectly the rising tempo of the music. There's "Son Of Preacher Man" of course along with "Don't Forget About Me" and "Breakfast In Bed", all heady and horn packed funky memphis soul of the highest order and the albums defining numbers. Of the bonus tracks "Willie & Laura Mae Jones" and "That Old Sweet Roll" showcase Dusty's understanding of how to deal vocally with slow crawling, roots rhythm & blues. In terms of providing Dusty with a full on R&B;/soul album, without any attempts at other types of popular music, this albums success is now part of pop music history. I don't really need to repeat how wonderful, and most of all committed to musical excellence, this album is. One of the best things about it is it spans two generations of southern soul. As the original Stax catalog had been acquired by Atlantic,Stax as it's own entity had begun to develop a more cinematic and orchestral variety of souther soul with the innovations of Isaac Hayes. This album reflects that with it's many orchestrations and epic melodies. Still the feeling is very subtle and effeminine in nature. But a soulful femininity. The sort that came from the Aretha's and Carla Thomas's of the world. And now, from Dusty Springfield.
summary: One Of Those Albums That Can Really Reach You

reviewText: Ok. There was a free savant jazz insurrection going on in the one thousand, nine hundred and sixty. I have been privileged to hear a good chunk of what Archie Shepp calledFire Music. That did not mean people forgot about good mainstream jazz and the blues it rests on. Lee Morgan was one of the top envoys of this music, and Sidewinder is one of this best albumsThis is simply creamy blues based hardtop with fantastic musicians and more than enough shuffle for one thousand feet. With this type of music, it is not the framework that is key--it is where the players go with it, and there, the soloing and backing work by all has amazing soul. I went to NYU in the late one thousand, nine hundred and heights and got to see Barry Harris, patio player on Sidewinder, in a jazz appreciation class. I did not know who I was meeting and good for him. I probably would now drive the poor man insane asking him about Blue Note, Lee Morgan, the one thousand, nine hundred and sixty, and Sidewinder.

The title track is reason enough to own this great LP. It's a jazzy, strutting, ethereal masterpiece of music that has't aged a day in almost thirty years (don't those cymbals and echoing snaredrum wafting in over the piano on the intro just give you the chills?) and stands as a major landmark in both movie music and the career of Marvin Gaye. The rest of this soundtrack is just that, beautiful 'sound'. The instrumentals that comprise this collection incorporate elements of jazz, soul, classical and light pop, to stunning effect. While the movie itself has't exactly endured very well, the accompanying music is timeless. Mr. Gaye had yet another classic on this hands.

reviewerName: Mark "The early bird gets the worm but the se...
reviewText: I'm a jazz guitar player. Not great, not too bad either. My listening is tuned into Kenny Burrell, Jim Hall, Pat Martino, Pat Metheny, and Wes Montgomery (though I still don't "get" this guy). I ashamed to admit that until yesterday, I did not own ANY Grant Green music even though I'd seen him as part of a CTI musicians tour back in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six. I seriously did't know what I was missing! Idle Moments is a wonderfully rich CD. All the guys show up and the chemistry is fantastic (just read the Duke Pearson liner notes as the describes how the title track at a whopping fourteen:fifty ended up being selected as the "master" take despite its length). There are few releases that I can say I feel are perfect. Obviously Kind of Blue and A Love Supreme, perhaps Blues and the Abstract Truth come to mind. Well This session is on par with say that great Oliver Nelson release I just noted. I used the adjective wonderfully rich to describe this music, that's the only thing I can think of. I can tell you that as much as I know about jazz and jazz guitar (which after thirty years of serious listening and playing I think I know quite a bit) I'm now going to have to rethink everything as far as who the "mutha" players are. Everybody likes to talk about Wes and this soul but I have to tell you that after hearing Idle Moments, I prefer Grant to Wes. does that make me some sort of jazz guitar heretic? If you like nice, laid back jazz with exceptional musicianship then you want Idle Moments. Green is fantastic but so are Pearson, Hutcherson, and Henderson. especially Henderson. I have to rethink that guy too. I always thought the was a atwood tier player. WRONG!
summary: Dang it!  Now I Have to Rethink Everything!
