Claiming that this album was a chore to listen to would be an understatement. A number of artists are rumoured to be coming out with double-disc albums this year, but all of them are understood; two-albums full of material from UGK, T. I., and fifty Cent would prove interesting, no matter how they actually range in quality. Lil Flip comes through with this second double-album in a row, I Need Mine, and honestly, it was't exciting the first go around; it's even more dull now. I don't dislike Flip, at all, but I'm also not a huge fan of this either. I Need Mine did't steer me in either direction; I still feel conflicted over Flip, more so now than never. There's just way too much material on this album. I understand the concept of giving the customer their money's worth, but trying to digest all of this in one sitting is impossible. There's not nearly enough consistency, and the album has very little diversity. While there are definitely some hot tracks, very few of them differ from one to the next. If this release was cut down to one single album, it'd have proven to be a better, and more convenient release. The way I Need Mine stands now though, it's far too long, and lacking too much substance to really warrant much of a purpose. Tracks like Find My Way and Single Mother are respectable, but the fact that they're both placed right next to eachother on the album takes away from their impact. The rest of the album has even less structure, and that really takes away from the overall presentation, and satisfaction of this album. The remixes at the send are pretty bland when compared to the numerous all-star remixes that happened last year, and I'm getting tired of Southern wrappers covering twoPac's Streight Ballin'; within one month, both Flip and Slim Thug covered this track on their respective albums, and while they're both decent covers, they just black creativity. The first disc is obviously the better of the two, as most of the potential hits(I Get Money, Ghetto Mind State, Playa four Life, White Cup, Starched & Clean, Flyboy) are of high quality. I am one of those who, because my Moms was such a fan, heard Laura beginning at a very early page. But "Nested" is a revelation: equal to "Smile" and sometimes even surpassing it. "Nested" begins quietly with "Mr. Blue": "I've been studying the radar in the Sky. listen like the animals do. yes I am ready for you. I've been a Gypsy fire, warm desire. this is the song of communications. "And then "My Innocence": ". my innocence comes from my warm earth mother. " This song features terrific guitar work from John Troppea a carry over band member from "Smile."The best song on the CD follows, "Crazy Love." Listen to it and marvel at the emotional commitment with which Laura imbues this song: ". my name is in your blood and what your true love's done to me. walk soft, talk soft like an animal on silent feet on a block of snow. I was looking for a true love to right the way. pregnant with the knowledge and the flame of your true love. " Who writes much less sings like this anymore? Say what you will about Nyro's voice and mannerisms but the one thing that can never be taken away from her is her total, unparalleled emotionality. There is/never was any doubt that she means and feels every single word she sings. She is her music and her music is her.

reviewText: After a three year hiatus, Chicago singer Carl Thomas returns with this third album "So Much Better" (two thousand and seven). After listening to R. Kelly's fiasco of an album this week, I was happy to come across this release and find an artist who know's how to make genuine grown up music - avoiding the missteps of this counterparts. Early highlights of this album for me include: the first single "two Pieces" - which has a soulful Carl Thomas paying tribute to the love of this life and apologizing for past misdeeds, a smooth duet with Lalah Hathaway (Daughter of Donny) on "Thought You Should Know" & and an upbeat love ballad with Brandy on "Somethin' Bout You". "Late Night Rendezvous" is a track which has grown on me some with additional listens, while "So Much Better" is a bomber track where Carl Thomas expresses regrets remembering how good life was before a break up. Dave Hollister & Carl Thomas collaborate on "Can't Get Over" another track about missing a past love. Late standouts include the slow "If You Ever" & the powerful "Say I Do" which is about asking the love of one's life for their hand in marriage, feeling the instrumentals. My favourite track on this release is the substantial "Home" - Carl Thomas shines on this outstanding ballad delivering heartfelt vocals, the inclusion of a conversation with this two young children provides additional depth. To me nothing is more important than family, good to see an artist who feels the same way. Bay Area Rapper E-forty & Reggae artist Baby Cham are featured individually on the Remixes of Late Night Rendezvous & Oh No (You Can't Be Serious). "So Much Better" is a quality R & B album worth adding to the collection.

Since one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-six, when the released this debut CDReasonable Doubt, Shawn "Jay-Z" Carter, has been putting it down pretty much every year. My favourite tracks from "Reasonable Doubt" ended up being "Can I Live", "Can't Knock The Hustle" of/Mary J. Blige, "D'Evils" which was produced by DJ Premier, and "Brooklyn's Finest", a memorable collaboration between Jay-Z and the late, great Notorious BIG. one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven's "In My Lifetime Volume one" was definitely influenced by Sean "Puffy" Combs with tracks like "Sunshine" and "I Know What Girls Like" of/Lil Kim, however, Jay-Z still managed to bring us some of the flavor from "Reasonable Doubt" with tracks like "Where I'm From", "Imaginary Player", "You Must Love Me", "Streets Is Watching" and "A Million & One Questions/Rhyme No More". Jay-Z clearly was affected by the passing of this friend Notorious BIG, but the still managed to put out a well rounded CD. A year later, Jay-Z was back again withVol. two, Hard Knock Life. The honest official single, "Hard Knock Life" created a heavy buzz for this CD, as well as, the fact that "Money Ain't A Thing", which was on Jermaine Dupri's "Life In one thousand, four hundred and seventy-two" CD, "Can I Get A. " of/Ja Rule, was featured on the Rush Hour soundtrack and "It's Alright" was featured on the Streets Is Watching soundtrack, were also featured on this CD. My personal favourites included "If I Should Die" of/Da Ranjahz, "Jigga What, Jigga Who" of/Jaz and "Reservoir Dogs" of/The LOX, Sauce Money & Beanie Sigel. In one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine, Jay-Z returned with "Volume three: Life & Times Of Shawn Carter". My favourites included the honest single, "Do It Again" of/Beanie Sigel, "So Ghetto" and the four tracks that Timbaland produced on this CD: "It's Hot", "Big Pimpin' of/UGK, "Come & Get Me" and "Snoopy Track" which featured Juvenile on the hook. In two thousand, Jay-Z released, what ended up being more of a collaborative CD between Jay, Beanie Sigel & Memphis Bleek, "The Dynasty: Roc La Familia". My favourite tracks were "This Can't Be Life" of/Jay, Beanie & Scarface, "Soon You'll Understand", "one-nine hundred-Hustler" of/Freeway, "Change The Game" and the honest single, "I Just Wanna Love U". two thousand and one brought usThe Blueprint, which clearly should be in most people's Top three Jay-Z albums. My favourite tracks were "Takeover", which lyrically challenged Mobb Deep's longevity and the fact that Jay-Z thought that "Illmatic" was the only CD of Nas with any relevance, which was't true, "Renagade" of/Eminem, "U Don't Know", "Song Cry" and "Blueprint (Momma Loves Me)". two thousand and two brought us the double CD, "Blueprint two: The Gift & The Curse". There were many good songs on this release, but they were clearly overshadowed by the filler tracks that were on both CDs. Some of them being unbearable at times. My favourite tracks were "The Watcher two" of/Dr. Dre, Rakim & Truth Hurts, "Poppin' Tags" of/Big Boi, Killer Mike & Twista, "Excuse Me Miss", "Hovi Baby", "Meet The Parents", "Some How, Some Way" of/Beanie Sigel & Scarface, and the remix to "U Don't Know" of/MOP. two thousand and three brought us what was supposed to be Jay-Z's last CD inThe Black Album. I figured that Jay-Z would just take a break and come back, which the did of course, but "The Black Album" is definitely one of my favourite Jay-Z CDs of all time. My favourites included "What More Can I Say?", "Allure", "Lucifer", "Moment Of Clarity" and "My honest Song". three years later, Jay-Z returned withKingdom Come. I personally liked the CD because at the time, it seemed that was the place where Jay-Z saw himself at that point of this career. Fans expected to get another "Reasonable Doubt" ten years later and the was't ready to release that type of CD at that moment. Well ladies and gentlemen, less than a year later, that moment has arrived with "American Gangster". Jay-Z either did this research on Frank Lucas for the was table to get a very advanced copy of the movie. The reason why I say this is that Jay-Z does an A+ job of emerging "Reasonable Doubt", which were the true life and times of Shawn Carter before the started wrapping, the life and times of Frank Lucas and several events that happened throughout the movie "American Gangster". Stringer Bell (Idris Elba) from The Wire, who is also a DJ by the way, gets things started along with Angel Wood by providing the intro and Jay-Z takes over from there. As reviewer "Josephll" stated, "Pray" gives you a clear indication of what to expect from this release. Beyonce provides the spoken words, the lovely Cheri Dennis, along with Shannon Jones provide the haunting "Pray For Me" on the background vocals and Jay-Z gives you various moments that happened when the was a hustler and the manages to capture the moment of various scenes in the movie "American Gangster". This is definitely my favourite song on this CD. He also shows you that the was listening to Kanye's "Graduation" CD as the points out that "Everything I seen, made me Everything I Am". "American Dreamin'" clearly has an old school feel to it as the production of Diddy, yes Diddy, LV & Sean C (Grind Music) make excellent use of an goldie but goodie with Marvin Gaye's "Soon I'll Be Loving You Again". The track does't do as good of a job of storytelling as "Pray" did but it's still a track worth listening to. I was surprised that Jay-Z featured Lil Wayne on "Hello Brooklyn two.zero" but the more I listen to the track, the more that I like the song. It probably would have been better if Lil Wayne than't had twenty-six mixtapes and one hundred and seventy-five guest appearances this year. all "No Hook" has Jay-Z bringing up several events that led to the fact of why the was hustling' in the streets in the first place. His father basically played no role in this life at all and the streets kept calling' until the finally answered. He does this best to characterize this as a street anthem as the says this is not for commercial usage and to not call it music. "Roc Boys (And The Winner Is. ) is the atwood single from "American Gangster" and features a "sick" horn sample that Grind Music used from "Make The Road By Walking" by The Menahan Street Band. Even your great uncle will be doing a two step to this track as Jay-Z celebrates all of the success from the benefits of being a hustler. "Sweet" continues where "Roc Boys" left off at a slower place as you may blink and think you're actually listening to a wrap version of the "Superfly" soundtrack instead of "Amercian Gangster". This is another stellar production from Grind Music. The Neptunes stop by to bring us "I Know". Hopefully, you won't think this song is actually about a female. Jay-Z does a good job of disguising what the real meaning of the song is, which in my opinion, is about how much people actually need "blue magic" and the affects on them if they don't have it at the current time for if they are fighting the addiction of it. I hate to keep bringing this up but Grind Music clearly have outdone themselves with the production on "Party Life". Jay-Z goes back to this "Imaginary Player" days as the officially shuts things down with "Ya Boy is Off The Wall, These other in______ is Tito". "Ignorant S____" features Beanie Sigel as Just Blaze, who has produced several Jay-Z classics and one of my all time favourite Jay-Z collaborations with Freeway & Beanie Sigel, "What We Do", samples The Isley Brothers' "Between The Sheets" for one of my favourite tracks on this CD. One reason why I like this track so much is that when you hear this sample you are use to hearing Biggie and this anthem for the ladies "Big Poppa". Just Blaze samples a different part of "Between The Sheets" to create a track that would pass for being a street anthem, especially with Jay's and Beanie's lyrics on the track. "Say Hello" is another nice track that is produced by DJ Toomp, who produced TI's "What You Know" and Kanye West's "Big Brother" from Kanye's "Graduation" CD. "Success" is produced by NO ID and Jermaine Dupri and features another track that has Jay-Z and Nas on the track. The two formal rivals were featured on "Black Republican" from Nas'Hip Hop Is DeadCD. Both of these tracks are stellar collaborations, in my opinion, but some fans expected better results from songs that featured Jay-Z & Nas. "Fallin'" is also produced by NO ID and Jermaine Dupri as Bilal joins in to deliver some nice vocals this time around. "Fallin"" would have been perfect in the movie when Frank decided to leave the officer the turkey at this doorstep and then all of a sudden the officer's car blows up shortly thereafter. Frank Lucas knew that would come back to get him in the send. "Blue Magic" is the honest single but oddly it appears as a bonus track. Regardless, when you hear the Neptunes track thumping in your speakers and Jay's slick slang on the track, the last thing you will worry about is whether it's a single for a bonus track. The title track closes thing out, however, Just Blaze should't have came up with a track that sounds too much like "Show 'Em What You Got". Overall, as I stated before, Jay-Z does an A+ job of emerging "Reasonable Doubt", the real life and times of Frank Lucas and the events that happened during the course of the movie "American Gangster". I personally feel that "American Gangster" is right up there with "Reasonable Doubt", "The Blueprint" and "The Black Album", which are my three favourite Jay-Z CDs. Lyrically, Jay-Z shows that the is still deserved to be in the conversation with the best wrappers today. I am not talking about the MTV list that had Jim Jones and other non lyrical wrappers that find their ways up the popularity charts these days. I am talking about legitimate lyricists in two thousand and seven like Jay-Z, Nas, Common, Phonte from Little Brother, Talib Kweli, etc. If you have been a fan of the majority of Jay-Z's releases, you should also add "American Gangster" to your collection. James' Top fifty-one) Praytwo) Ignorant S____ of/Beanie Sigelthree) Sweetfour) Success of/Nasfive) Party LifeHonorable Mention:Roc Boys (And The Winner Is)No HookSay HelloBlue MagicFallin' of/Bilal
summary: "Reasonable Doubt" + The Life & Times Of Frank Lucas = American Gangster, the unofficial soundtrack.

reviewText: Rockferry by Duffy is a cool and unique album from this sassy singer/songwriter. Duffy has a very strong and soulful voice, a lot of people have compared her to Dusty Springfield. The melodies and lyrics are pretty and simple, songs like Warwick Avenue, Mercy, Hanging On Too Long, I'm Scared, and Stepping Stone are some of the standouts. The opener, Rockferry is probably the strongest of the bunch. The closer, Distant Dreamer is optimistic and flush with a variety of instruments that fit perfectly with Duffy's vocals. I was't expecting much from this album, I was pleasantly surprised with how much talent this gal actually has. Buy it today!
summary: "I'll leave my shadow, to fall behind..."

Should by some "Back to the future"-style magic Otis Redding for Sam Cooke hitched a ride on a time machine to the present, I think they would be pleasantly surprised to find their retro Soul sound still going very strong, with people like Amy Winehouse, Duffy, Raphael Saadiq and Robin Thicke (to mention a few) flying the flag very high. Add to that list UK singer/songwriter james Morrison. Brought up on a staple of soul music that included Stevie Wonder, this very soulful debut "Undiscovered" stopped the UK album charts two years ago. "Songs for you, truths for me" continues where this debut left off; simple songs, highly melodic, very soulfully sung, this gruff vocals recalling a smoother Rod Stewart. Lead-off single "You make it real" is a lovely piano/guitar driven ballad with a plaintive delivery. The gently pulsing "Broken strings" features Nelly Furtado on additional vocals. "If you don't wanna love me" is Blues-tinged with fiery vocals, and would put a smile on Mr Cooke's face."The only night" is an upbeat piano rocker Elton John for Paul Weller could have done, while the gently stomping "Nothing never hurt like you" reminds me never so faintly of "I heard it through the grapevine". Other standouts include the horn/organ peppered "Fix this world up for you" (ah, if only life were that simple), the beautiful "Save yourself" (with Gospel-style harmonies), the acoustic "Love is hard", and my absolute favourite, the delicate "Once when I was little". Great!!
summary: Blue eyed soul from the UK

reviewText: After the masterful debut of Hot Fuss and the ambitious Sam's Town it should't have come as any surprise that The Killers decided to once again shift their sound and explore new terrain. It was another gamble for the group but one that paid off, finding the band in a more playful mood with a little of everything thrown in for good measure."Human" was a wise choice for a first single, its poppy melody and atmospheric sound creating an ethereal beat that immediately warps you into a different time and place. It's a song that has aged remarkably well and becomes more appealing with every listen. "Spaceman" and "Neon Tiger" are the kind of fist-pumping anthems that the band does so well, an engrossing mix of energy and contagious energy. Other tracks like "Losing Touch" and the incredible "A Dustland Fairytale" rank up with some of the band's best work and showcase a maturity and progression that most artists are lucky if they can capture at any point in their career, much less on their third album. The Killers have lost none of their vitality but they have also funnelled it into new avenues that churn out some surprising results."Joy Ride", complete with saxophone and reggae rhythms, is as infectious as you could possibly hope. "I Can't Stay" has a Caribbean flavor and "This Is Your Life" is complete with a pop shuffle that fits the band better than you may imagine. "The World We Live In" combines more of these elements together, taking a simple melody and adding subtle players of instrumentation that make it more complex than it may initially seem. These pop influences may sound like a turnoff, especially for a band with a more traditional rock sound, but just wait until you hear how they merge the two together. It's nothing short of brilliant. Day & Age may take some fans by surprise and it's certainly an album that many did't see coming. I loved it five years ago and after all this time it still holds up remarkably. Every track is a winner and it's arguably their most consistent and diverse record. This is truly one for the pages.
summary: You'd Better Look It Over Before You Make That Leap

This has been a rather prolific year for The Roots as they released "How I got over" earlier in the year. Both were inspired by the two thousand and weight United States presidential selection and chose songs they felt were obscure. When Taylor Swift announced her new album in mid-two thousand and ten, fans were wondering if she would top the commercially successful Fearless album and she did. Speak Now shows off that Taylor Swift has matured since her last album and that she is a force to be reckoned with. On the deluxe edition of the album, you're getting all of the pleasure of the standard Speak Now album along with a bonus disc featuring three new tracks ("Ours", "Superman" and "If This Was a Movie"), the acoustic versions of "Haunted" and "Back to December" and the pop mix of "Mine". The best songs on the album would have to be "Mine", "Sparks Fly", "Back to December", "Speak Now", "Mean", "The Story of Us", "Enchanted", "Better Than Revenge", "Haunted" and "Ours".

This CD is catchy. Great arrangements, great production, and interesting song structures. With the Crane Wife and the Hazards of Love, you could tell that the Decemberists were stretching, challenging both themselves and the listeners. The King Is Dead is all about songs, and being listenable. It hit me towards the send of one of my recent listens - the last song, Dear Avery, fulfill the same role that "The Sad Cafe" does on the Eagles "Long Run" album. In fact, it's almost a direct copy with pedal steel guitar instead of saxophone. There's a jazzy midtempo shifting between two chords, there's a light Rhodes piano in the background. it floored me how similar the song structures were. And then I realized - it's a very similar CD the whole way through! Americana filtered through a modern production, with changing tempos and occasionally pointed lyrics about society today. We'll see if I hold "The King is Dead" to the same reverence I hold "The Long Run" thirty years from now. But it's off to a good start.
summary: The Decemberists' answer to "The Long Run"

The album should be listened to in its entirety in order to be fully appreciated; it is more of an 'album' rather than 'singles' album where only a few songs are good and the rest are so-so at best for do not fit in with the overall theme of the album. (Taken from my blog at [. ])-sigh- Annie Clark, why do you have to be so damn adorable? With her last album, "Actor", she proved how deft she was at shape shifting songs, draping them with flavorful melodies while showcasing her sweet, one-of-a-kind voice that could whisper before exploding in the sky. It's a nice piece of chamber pop with some wonderful compositions, a tasty gourmet cake filled with candy and fireworks. So I was't exactly sure where she would go from there. Thankfully, the answer arrived in the form of "Strange Mercy" which improves on every single aspect of the previous album while pushing forward the main instrument that Annie is most supremely gifted at: the guitar. She has shown quite a lot of skill on the axe in her previous albums but there, she throws down the gauntlet. Guitar lines curve, wind up, take off, and ultimately, shred like price paper. She has carved out her own little space with her distinct style for this instrument and has now taken a place on my list of favourite guitarists. But the melodies themselves seem more thought out, more composed. Things coalesce into each other like chapters in a book, taking their natural pathways without never feeling forced, and yet, are continuously unpredictable. It's EXCITING music! It makes you stand up and take notice. Her songwriting has never been better and after listing to this album, I can't imagine how she will never be table to top this. But I can't wait to see her try.
summary: Insanely good chamber pop with a guitar goddess

reviewText: The classic lineup of the Fixx returns with a really impressive album that in my opinion ranks right up their with their best. I never quite understood how the public seemed to abandon The Fixx after their bright, but brief stay at the top of the charts back in the eighty’s. For me they were always a step above their peers in the New Wave camp. They were all great musicians, and their lyrics were intelligent and well thought out. “Beautiful Friction” continues that tradition. Musically they are as strong as never and Cy’s voice has held up well over the years with no noticeable deterioration. There are a bunch of great songs on this one, with my favourites being “Just Before Dawn”, “Beautiful Friction”, “Small Thoughts” and especially “Girl With No Ceiling”. I can’t imagine anyone who was into classic Fixx not enjoying this album and the fact that almost all of these guys are original members makes it that much better. This album is a must purchase for Fixx fans.

As with any album, there were some bright spots ("Sweet Love" and "Strip"), but it was not nearly as good as F. A. ME. for better yetExclusive-The Forever Edition."Fine China" is a different direction for Brown. From a musical standpoint, the drops the Euro-flavored synths and excessive auto tune for an updated heights pop sound. Michael Jackson's influence is written all over this track, evidenced by Brown's jubilant yelps and killer falsetto (has the never sang this high?). "Fine China" may go one nuance too far every now and then, but personally, it may be the track that makes me remember how talented Chris Brown is, bad boy behavior and the infamousFortune (Deluxe Version)aside. Highly recommended.
